body:
Further testing seems to reveal that this may be related to ` --fast-list` on mount command. 
It maybe causing the issue. `--fast-list` to rc command has no affect

> If the parameter recursive=true is given the whole directory tree will get refreshed. This refresh will use --fast-list if enabled.

Does that mean that --fast-list is being used by default when recursive=true is enabled and no need to add it to the rc command ? Or do we have to add specify it explicitly (eg  vfs/refresh)?

Also what benefit would running vfs/refresh give you vs running something like find {mount} ?

Also of note having --fast-list on mount command speeds up vfs/refresh tremendously. 
>2019/01/31 18:57:18 DEBUG : rclone: Version "v1.45" starting with parameters
2019/01/31 18:58:10 DEBUG : rclone: Version "v1.45" finishing with parameters

Adding it to the vfs/refresh command itself and not on the mount had no affect and took a very long time. I gave up around 15min. 

Running rclone v1.45

> Does that mean that --fast-list is being used by default when recursive=true is enabled and no need to add it to the rc command ? Or do we have to add specify it explicitly (eg vfs/refresh)?

That is correct, `--fast-list` should be automatically enabled for `vfs/refresh` if the backend supports it.
@ncw any insights or ideas on this other issue?

> Further testing seems to reveal that this may be related to ` --fast-list` on mount command.
> It maybe causing the issue. `--fast-list` to rc command has no affect

Are you saying that the issue went away if you stopped using `--fast-list` on the mount?

As far as I can see `--fast-list` should do nothing when using the mount.

If the issue is still present a bit more info would be helpful.

Can you show the command line you are using for the mount?

Which backend are you using?

If you could do diff the output of the `ls -lrth /mnt/remote/Media/TV` commands and work out what is missing that would be helpful too.

> Also what benefit would running vfs/refresh give you vs running something like find {mount} ?

    rclone rc vfs/refresh recursive=true

should be much quicker than using find

I was helping him troubleshoot this in the cloudbox discord channel.  

> Are you saying that the issue went away if you stopped using --fast-list on the mount?

In @H1XYZ case yes. In my case it actually caused vfs/refresh to take forever and not finish before the timeout. Once added back to the mount it worked within 2minutes and no missing dirs.
> Can you show the command line you are using for the mount?


rclone mount command used: `/usr/bin/rclone mount --config=/home/user/.config/rclone/rclone.conf --allow-other --rc --rc-addr=localhost:5572 --fast-list --drive-skip-gdocs --vfs-read-chunk-size=64M --vfs-read-chunk-size-limit=2048M --buffer-size=64M --max-read-ahead=256M --poll-interval=30s --dir-cache-time=168h --timeout=10m --transfers=20 --checkers=16 --fuse-flag=sync_read --fuse-flag=auto_cache --drive-chunk-size=64M --umask=002 --syslog -v google: /mnt/remote`

rclone vfs refresh used : `/usr/bin/rclone --config /home/user/.config/rclone/rclone.conf --timeout=1h -vvv rc --rc-addr=localhost:5572 vfs/refresh dir=Media recursive=true`

> Which backend are you using?

gdrive

> If you could do diff the output of the ls -lrth /mnt/remote/Media/TV commands and work out what is missing that would be helpful too.

@H1XYZ will provide this once he is capable of doing so. What we noticed also was there wasn't a consistent number of directories that were missing. Sometimes only 49,61,62,88,134 should show up out of 323 or so.

I have not been able to reproduce his issue. Having `--fist-list` on the mount command though does seen to cause  rclone vfs/refresh command to run a lot faster in my and other cases. In my case it finishes up a 225TB gdrive in 1.5minutes. However once I remove it from the mount command it caused it to be very slow where it would time out. 

There seems to be two issues here. 
1) vfs/refresh causing dirs to not be cached or are missing. (H1XYZ) issue
2) Removing vfs/refresh from the mount command causes it to not run properly and/or be very slow and timed out. (Others have experienced this)

> There seems to be two issues here.
> 
> 1. vfs/refresh causing dirs to not be cached or are missing. (H1XYZ) issue
> 2. Removing --fast-list from the mount command causes vfs/refresh to not run properly and/or be very slow and timed out. (Others have experienced this)

The second issue is a bug which I've attempted to fix here - can you have a go?

https://beta.rclone.org/branch/v1.45-168-g06c1447e-fix-2946-dirtree-beta/ (uploaded in 15-30 mins)

The first is a bug too, but I haven't managed to replicate it either.

@ncw 
pre vfs / refresh: https://pastebin.com/raw/XBRh7Bz4 (323 count)
post vfs / refresh: https://pastebin.com/raw/zfMDXyaV (122 count)

I have done this multiple times, the post refresh results vary each time in terms of total dir count, which tells me it stalls randomly. When i did the tests above a second time, only 83 dirs appeared post refresh. In another test, only 44.

Update: I tried API keys from a completely different account - still the same issue persists. 

Update2: Tried the binary you posted, the refresh issue still exists with it

> The second issue is a bug which I've attempted to fix here - can you have a go?
https://beta.rclone.org/branch/v1.45-168-g06c1447e-fix-2946-dirtree-beta/ (uploaded in 15-30 mins)

I can confirm this does fix the issue of slow running vfs/refresh when mount does not have --fast-list.
Is there a way to bump up the logs on vfs/refresh or something see why it might not be caching all of @H1XYZ  dirs ?

> > The second issue is a bug which I've attempted to fix here - can you have a go?
> > https://beta.rclone.org/branch/v1.45-168-g06c1447e-fix-2946-dirtree-beta/ (uploaded in 15-30 mins)
> 
> I can confirm this does fix the issue of slow running vfs/refresh when mount does not have --fast-list.

I've merged this to master now which means it will be in [the latest beta](https://beta.rclone.org) in 15-30 mins and released in v1.46



> Is there a way to bump up the logs on vfs/refresh or something see why it might not be caching all of @H1XYZ dirs ?

You could stick some `log.Printf` in the source - that is probably what I'd do!

Can you try an experiment.  I suspect it is the --fast-list support for drive which is the problem.

Can you do

    rclone lsf -R gdrive:troublesomedir | sort > test0
    rclone lsf --fast-list -R gdrive:troublesomedir | sort > test1
    rclone lsf --fast-list -R gdrive:troublesomedir | sort > test2

And then run

    diff -u test0 test1
    diff -u test1 test2

And see what differences there are - if any?

If --fast-list is working properly there should be no differences.
I should have thought of this before, but if there are duplicate directories this could explain everything!  So run `rclone dedupe`...

@ncw 
i did run `rclone dedupe` earlier but there are no duplicates. 
The issue also happens on other directories so i know it's not that.

The diff commands had no difference noted. 

Also did:
`rclone lsf -R google:Media/TV/ | wc -l
51811`

`rclone lsf --fast-list -R google:Media/TV/ | wc -l
51811`

There was no difference in files or count however --fast-list was significantly faster when running
